intro: Parinari griffithiana, commonly known as the Indian satinwood, is a deciduous tree native to Southeast Asia and parts of the Indian subcontinent. It belongs to the family Sapotaceae and is characterized by its smooth, gray bark and simple, alternate leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are followed by oval, woody fruits containing a single seed. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often found in moist, well-drained soils. Due to its ornamental value and timber quality, it is sometimes cultivated in horticulture and agroforestry systems.
